awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Urban Transport Network Design with Privacy-Aware Agent Learning
awd_abstract_narration:
Technological advances for transportation systems are quickly evolving from their roots in highway materials and traffic control 70 years ago to technologies that support "smart cities": autonomous vehicles, on-demand mobility services, and traffic control with machine learning, among others. In 2016, the U.S. Department of Transportation proposed spending $4 billion on autonomous vehicles, and pledged $40 million in tackling smart cities as a grand challenge. However, successful operation of these technologies in a large scale, highly congested city remains prone to operational pitfalls and obstacles. For example, how should a service operator best deploy their vehicles or inform their travelers in real time to optimize service and learning potential simultaneously, while acknowledging their privacy? Some high profile failures include the on-demand transit service Kutsuplus in Helsinki and the Car2Go car share service in San Diego. These systems are highly dynamic, but methods in machine learning and dynamic optimization are not designed for the unique intricacies of urban transport networks. This Faculty Early Career Development (CAREER) Program project is for integrated research and advanced education to create new technologies for these dynamic systems, train students and professionals in these technologies, and engage with private operators and incubators in New York City to operationalize them. The project will use real data from industry partners in ridesharing and autonomous vehicle systems operations, and drive innovation and entrepreneurship by defining new functional roles that mix transportation, computer science, and economics. This will culminate in a test bed in New York City that is expected to shape a next-generation national interdisciplinary research center on "smart transit" over the next decade. The PI will recruit local high school students to work with his PhD students each summer; the high school students will be identified through the university's ARISE (Applied Research Innovations in Science and Engineering) program which creates STEM education experiences for women, minorities, and students from low-income backgrounds.  

The research marries three theories together in order to address these new mobility problems in smart cities: dynamic resource allocation under uncertainty, agent-based machine learning, and privacy optimization in a network context. All three are necessary because transportation systems need to be optimized holistically, but data is typically obtained from multiple travelers or vehicles in operation. As such, agent learning and minimization of privacy concerns in the system optimization is needed. The methodology expands the science of inverse optimization by integrating it with dynamic network optimization with privacy control as constraints on the estimated parameters. The research benefits all types of dynamic mobility systems: it will make shared autonomous vehicle fleet operations viable and on-demand service fleets more sustainable and resilient. Data privacy and security in a transport system design context will also be advanced, allowing data from travelers to be more accessible. This research will benefit smart cities, sensor deployment, artificial intelligence, collective behavior, differential privacy, service systems, public policy, and network economics.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

por.por_cntn:
The objective of this project was to expand the science on transportation systems modeling to account for emerging technologies. The following key outcomes emerged from the project as a result:

  • The PI authored a book that encompassed the broad area of transportation systems analysis, adding modern concepts to classic treatments on systems analysis, network equilibria, and network design, with new concepts that include city monitoring, data privacy control, machine learning and reinforcement learning in network design. (see Primary Image)
  • We invented an algorithm to monitor a transportation network that is statistically efficient by relying on agent network behavior, that can explain when, how, and why the system state changes.
  • We invented a new privacy control algorithm for taking sensitive operator data (which we illustrate how it can be used to reverse engineer the policy) and synthesizing similar data that can still be useful for policy analysis.
  • We discovered a new machine learning-based estimation method for individual-varying choice models that can be more accurate, more informative, and easier to integrate with systems design optimization models. 
  • We invented two new algorithms for designing networks sequentially, which are of particular value for emerging technologies with limited data. The two algorithms make use of reinforcement learning methods to either improve the optimization or learning efficiency, applied to service region design and public transit route design.
  • We discovered a new model for explaining the market equilibrium of a platform of multiple mobility operators, that generalizes a 70-year-old principle on route assignment that incorporates operator decisions, can explain market entry and multimodal behavior, justify subsidies, and explain when equity measures need to be taken. 

These discoveries led to publications in one book, eleven journal articles, and many more conference proceedings and working papers under review for journal publication. Six PhD students were involved in the project as well as one MS student, and several undergraduate and K-12 students under summer research programs. The research helped create and expand courses at NYU, including graduate courses on Urban Transportation & Logistics Systems, Travel Behavioral Informatics, and Public Transit, and undergraduate course Transportation Systems Analytics, resulting in a new undergraduate Minor in Transportation. The PI received the 2018 New Faculty Award from the Council of University Transportation Centers, and became one of the Top 2% of scientists worldwide in the subfield of Logistics & Transportation career-wide as of 2022.

The work made it into a case study in the World Economic Forum's Shared, Electric Automated Mobility Governance Framework in 2019, led to a sole source contract with the Federal Transit Administration to create a guide for them on microtransit services. The PI was a National Expert on an awarded team for on-call to revise the data collection an analysis efforts at Bureau of Transportation Statistics. The PI was invited to help NYS DOT to develop a procurement for updating their 511NY Rideshare program to consider more Mobility-as-a-Service features. The research also led to a project with MOIA/Volkswagen to help them design new fleet management algorithms.

The PI was invited to multiple lectures and talks regarding this project's work, including the Federal Transit Administration in 2018; The Networking and Information Technology Research and Development (NITRD) Program in 2019; the Institute for Pure & Applied Mathematics (IPAM) Large Scale Autonomy Workshop in UCLA in 2020; participation in the selective Dagstuhl Seminar on Dynamic Traffic Models in Transportation Science; and as a keynote speaker at the TU Delft Transport Institute Workshop on "Dynamic and real-time decisions for emerging transport systems" in 2023.


Last Modified: 05/20/2023
Modified by: Joseph Chow

Images (1 of )
  • Book written as part of the grant in which classic transportation modeling methods are modernized with concepts that include city monitoring, data privacy, and reinforcement learning in network design
    Elsevier
    Copyrighted
    Joseph Chow
    Cover for authored book in Elsevier
  • To better understand data sharing, vehicle routing data can be used to reverse engineer the underlying policy, this justifies having better privacy control algorithms to generate synthetic data
    Elsevier
    Copyrighted
    Joseph Chow
    Example vehicle tour data used to reverse engineer an operator's policy
  • Illustration of network learning methodology developed from this grant for monitoring a transportation network over time.
    INFORMS
    Copyrighted
    Joseph Chow
    Illustration of real time data from Google Maps of Queens NY (left) and capacity impacts over time (right)
  • New machine learning-estimated individual parameter logit is shown to be more accurate, informative, and integrative than state of the art choice models for complex activity based modeling using Shanghai Big Data
    Elsevier
    Copyrighted
    Joseph Chow
    Case study of agent-based mixed logit model for Shanghai
  • Two examples of AI-embedded network design methods: (left) RNN in service region design, (right) optimal learning in transit network design
    Joseph Chow (arxiv)
    Royalty-free (restricted use - cannot be shared)
    Joseph Chow
    Two examples of AI-embedded network design methods: (left) RNN in service region design, (right) optimal learning in transit network design
  • Illustration of market equilibrium model for multi-operator setting for MaaS platform, illustrating sensitivity to capturing multimodal trip behavior, subsidies, and impact on equity.
    Joseph Chow (arxiv)
    Royalty-free (restricted use - cannot be shared)
    Joseph Chow
    Illustration of market equilibrium model for multi-operator setting for MaaS platform
